natural problem: What is the greatest number of points of intersection that can occur when $2$ different circles and $2$ different straight lines are drawn on the same piece of paper?
natural solution: Make a diagram. Two geometric figures intersect if they have one or more points in common. Draw two circles which intersect in $2$ points. Draw a line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points. Draw another line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points and also intersects the first line.

There are $\boxed{11}$ points of intersection. [asy] draw(Circle((-0.7,0),1)); draw(Circle((0.7,0),1)); dot((0,0)); dot((0,0.7)); dot((0,-0.7)); draw((0,0)--(-2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(-2,-0.6),Arrow);

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes circles lines :: nat
assumes h0 : "circles = 2"
and h1 : "lines = 2"
shows  "MaxIntersections circles lines = 11"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest number of points of intersection that can occur when $2$ different circles and $2$ different straight lines are drawn on the same piece of paper? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Make a diagram. Two geometric figures intersect if they have one or more points in common. Draw two circles which intersect in $2$ points. Draw a line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points. Draw another line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points and also intersects the first line.
 There are $\boxed{11}$ points of intersection. [asy] draw(Circle((-0.7,0),1)); draw(Circle((0.7,0),1)); dot((0,0)); dot((0,0.7)); dot((0,-0.7)); draw((0,0)--(-2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(-2,-0.6),Arrow);
 draw((0,0)--(2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(2,-0.6),Arrow); dot((-1.58,0.47)); dot((-1.58,-0.47)); dot((1.58,0.47)); dot((1.58,-0.47)); dot((-0.29,0.08)); dot((-0.29,-0.08)); dot((0.29,0.08)); dot((0.29,-0.08));
 [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes circles lines :: nat
assumes h0 : "circles = 2"
and h1 : "lines = 2"
shows  "MaxIntersections circles lines = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two circles and two lines, find the maximum number of intersections. The final answer is 11.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes circles lines intersections :: nat
assumes h0 : "circles = 2"
and h1 : "lines = 2"
and h2 : "intersections = circles * (circles - 1) + 2 * circles * lines + lines * (lines - 1) / 2"
shows  "intersections = 11"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest number of points of intersection that can occur when $2$ different circles and $2$ different straight lines are drawn on the same piece of paper? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Make a diagram. Two geometric figures intersect if they have one or more points in common. Draw two circles which intersect in $2$ points. Draw a line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points. Draw another line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points and also intersects the first line.
 There are $\boxed{11}$ points of intersection. [asy] draw(Circle((-0.7,0),1)); draw(Circle((0.7,0),1)); dot((0,0)); dot((0,0.7)); dot((0,-0.7)); draw((0,0)--(-2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(-2,-0.6),Arrow);
 draw((0,0)--(2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(2,-0.6),Arrow); dot((-1.58,0.47)); dot((-1.58,-0.47)); dot((1.58,0.47)); dot((1.58,-0.47)); dot((-0.29,0.08)); dot((-0.29,-0.08)); dot((0.29,0.08)); dot((0.29,-0.08));
 [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes circles lines intersections :: nat
assumes h0 : "circles = 2"
and h1 : "lines = 2"
and h2 : "intersections = circles * (circles - 1) + 2 * circles * lines + lines * (lines - 1) / 2"
shows  "intersections = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If there are 2 circles and 2 lines, find the total number of intersections. The intersections can occur between circles (where each pair of circles intersects), between circles and lines (where each circle intersects with each line twice), and between lines (where each pair of lines intersects). The final answer is 11.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c1 c2 l1 l2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c1 \<noteq> c2"
and h1 : "l1 \<noteq> l2"
shows  "(card {x. c1 x = c2 x} \<union> {x. c1 x = l1 x} \<union> {x. c1 x = l2 x} \<union> {x. c2 x = l1 x} \<union> {x. c2 x = l2 x} \<union> {x. l1 x = l2 x}) = 11"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest number of points of intersection that can occur when $2$ different circles and $2$ different straight lines are drawn on the same piece of paper? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Make a diagram. Two geometric figures intersect if they have one or more points in common. Draw two circles which intersect in $2$ points. Draw a line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points. Draw another line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points and also intersects the first line.
 There are $\boxed{11}$ points of intersection. [asy] draw(Circle((-0.7,0),1)); draw(Circle((0.7,0),1)); dot((0,0)); dot((0,0.7)); dot((0,-0.7)); draw((0,0)--(-2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(-2,-0.6),Arrow);
 draw((0,0)--(2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(2,-0.6),Arrow); dot((-1.58,0.47)); dot((-1.58,-0.47)); dot((1.58,0.47)); dot((1.58,-0.47)); dot((-0.29,0.08)); dot((-0.29,-0.08)); dot((0.29,0.08)); dot((0.29,-0.08));
 [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes c1 c2 l1 l2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c1 \<noteq> c2"
and h1 : "l1 \<noteq> l2"
shows  "(card {x. c1 x = c2 x} \<union> {x. c1 x = l1 x} \<union> {x. c1 x = l2 x} \<union> {x. c2 x = l1 x} \<union> {x. c2 x = l2 x} \<union> {x. l1 x = l2 x}) = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: "How many unique solutions exist across all the equations where two distinct functions $c1, c2, l1, l2$ are set equal to each other? The final answer is 11."

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes points :: nat
assumes h0 : "points = (2 * 2) + (2 * 1) + (2 * 1) + (2 * 2) + 1"
shows  "points = 11"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest number of points of intersection that can occur when $2$ different circles and $2$ different straight lines are drawn on the same piece of paper? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Make a diagram. Two geometric figures intersect if they have one or more points in common. Draw two circles which intersect in $2$ points. Draw a line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points. Draw another line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points and also intersects the first line.
 There are $\boxed{11}$ points of intersection. [asy] draw(Circle((-0.7,0),1)); draw(Circle((0.7,0),1)); dot((0,0)); dot((0,0.7)); dot((0,-0.7)); draw((0,0)--(-2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(-2,-0.6),Arrow);
 draw((0,0)--(2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(2,-0.6),Arrow); dot((-1.58,0.47)); dot((-1.58,-0.47)); dot((1.58,0.47)); dot((1.58,-0.47)); dot((-0.29,0.08)); dot((-0.29,-0.08)); dot((0.29,0.08)); dot((0.29,-0.08));
 [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes points :: nat
assumes h0 : "points = (2 * 2) + (2 * 1) + (2 * 1) + (2 * 2) + 1"
shows  "points = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Calculate the total number of points given that you have two sets of two points, two sets of one point, one set of two points, and one extra point. The final answer is 11 points.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes circle1 circle2 line1 line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "circle1 \<noteq> circle2"
and h1 : "line1 \<noteq> line2"
shows  "\<exists> n. n \<le> 11 \<and> (\<exists> x y. circle1 x = y \<and> circle2 x = y \<and> line1 x = y \<and> line2 x = y)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest number of points of intersection that can occur when $2$ different circles and $2$ different straight lines are drawn on the same piece of paper? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Make a diagram. Two geometric figures intersect if they have one or more points in common. Draw two circles which intersect in $2$ points. Draw a line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points. Draw another line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points and also intersects the first line.
 There are $\boxed{11}$ points of intersection. [asy] draw(Circle((-0.7,0),1)); draw(Circle((0.7,0),1)); dot((0,0)); dot((0,0.7)); dot((0,-0.7)); draw((0,0)--(-2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(-2,-0.6),Arrow);

theorem
fixes circle1 circle2 line1 line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "circle1 \<noteq> circle2"
and h1 : "line1 \<noteq> line2"
shows  "\<exists> n. n \<le> 11 \<and> (\<exists> x y. circle1 x = y \<and> circle2 x = y \<and> line1 x = y \<and> line2 x = y)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find a number, less than or equal to 11, at which two distinct circles and two distinct lines intersect.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem max_intersections:
fixes circle1 circle2 line1 line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "circle1 \<noteq> circle2"
and h1 : "line1 \<noteq> line2"
shows  "\<exists>points. size points = 11 \<and> (\<forall>p \<in> points. (p \<in> circle1 \<and> p \<in> circle2) \<or> (p \<in> circle1 \<and> p \<in> line1) \<or> (p \<in> circle1 \<and> p \<in> line2) \<or> (p \<in> circle2 \<and> p \<in> line1) \<or> (p \<in> circle2 \<and> p \<in> line2) \<or> (p \<in> line1 \<and> p \<in> line2))"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest number of points of intersection that can occur when $2$ different circles and $2$ different straight lines are drawn on the same piece of paper? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Make a diagram. Two geometric figures intersect if they have one or more points in common. Draw two circles which intersect in $2$ points. Draw a line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points. Draw another line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points and also intersects the first line.
 There are $\boxed{11}$ points of intersection. [asy] draw(Circle((-0.7,0),1)); draw(Circle((0.7,0),1)); dot((0,0)); dot((0,0.7)); dot((0,-0.7)); draw((0,0)--(-2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(-2,-0.6),Arrow);
 draw((0,0)--(2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(2,-0.6),Arrow); dot((-1.58,0.47)); dot((-1.58,-0.47)); dot((1.58,0.47)); dot((1.58,-0.47)); dot((-0.29,0.08)); dot((-0.29,-0.08)); dot((0.29,0.08)); dot((0.29,-0.08));
 [/asy]
 *)

theorem max_intersections:
fixes circle1 circle2 line1 line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "circle1 \<noteq> circle2"
and h1 : "line1 \<noteq> line2"
shows  "\<exists>points. size points = 11 \<and> (\<forall>p \<in> points. (p \<in> circle1 \<and> p \<in> circle2) \<or> (p \<in> circle1 \<and> p \<in> line1) \<or> (p \<in> circle1 \<and> p \<in> line2) \<or> (p \<in> circle2 \<and> p \<in> line1) \<or> (p \<in> circle2 \<and> p \<in> line2) \<or> (p \<in> line1 \<and> p \<in> line2))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Assume you have two distinct circles and two distinct lines. Find a set of 11 points such that each point is either on both circles, on one of the circles and one of the lines, or on both lines.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Circle1 Circle2 Line1 Line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "Circle1 \<noteq> Circle2"
and h1 : "Line1 \<noteq> Line2"
shows  "card {(x, y). Circle1 x = Circle2 y \<or> Line1 x = Line2 y \<or> Circle1 x = Line1 y \<or> Circle2 x = Line2 y} \<le> 11"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest number of points of intersection that can occur when $2$ different circles and $2$ different straight lines are drawn on the same piece of paper? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Make a diagram. Two geometric figures intersect if they have one or more points in common. Draw two circles which intersect in $2$ points. Draw a line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points. Draw another line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points and also intersects the first line.
 There are $\boxed{11}$ points of intersection. [asy] draw(Circle((-0.7,0),1)); draw(Circle((0.7,0),1)); dot((0,0)); dot((0,0.7)); dot((0,-0.7)); draw((0,0)--(-2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(-2,-0.6),Arrow);
 draw((0,0)--(2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(2,-0.6),Arrow); dot((-1.58,0.47)); dot((-1.58,-0.47)); dot((1.58,0.47)); dot((1.58,-0.47)); dot((-0.29,0.08)); dot((-0.29,-0.08)); dot((0.29,0.08)); dot((0.29,-0.08));
 [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes Circle1 Circle2 Line1 Line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "Circle1 \<noteq> Circle2"
and h1 : "Line1 \<noteq> Line2"
shows  "card {(x, y). Circle1 x = Circle2 y \<or> Line1 x = Line2 y \<or> Circle1 x = Line1 y \<or> Circle2 x = Line2 y} \<le> 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the maximum possible number of intersections between two distinct circles and two distinct lines. The final answer is 11.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c1 c2 l1 l2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> l1 \<noteq> l2"
shows  "(card (roots c1 \<inter> roots c2) + card (roots l1 \<inter> roots l2) + card (roots c1 \<inter> roots l1) + card (roots c1 \<inter> roots l2) + card (roots c2 \<inter> roots l1) + card (roots c2 \<inter> roots l2)) \<le> 11"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest number of points of intersection that can occur when $2$ different circles and $2$ different straight lines are drawn on the same piece of paper? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Make a diagram. Two geometric figures intersect if they have one or more points in common. Draw two circles which intersect in $2$ points. Draw a line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points. Draw another line which intersects the two circles in $4$ points and also intersects the first line.
 There are $\boxed{11}$ points of intersection. [asy] draw(Circle((-0.7,0),1)); draw(Circle((0.7,0),1)); dot((0,0)); dot((0,0.7)); dot((0,-0.7)); draw((0,0)--(-2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(-2,-0.6),Arrow);
 draw((0,0)--(2,0.6),Arrow); draw((0,0)--(2,-0.6),Arrow); dot((-1.58,0.47)); dot((-1.58,-0.47)); dot((1.58,0.47)); dot((1.58,-0.47)); dot((-0.29,0.08)); dot((-0.29,-0.08)); dot((0.29,0.08)); dot((0.29,-0.08));
 [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes c1 c2 l1 l2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> l1 \<noteq> l2"
shows  "(card (roots c1 \<inter> roots c2) + card (roots l1 \<inter> roots l2) + card (roots c1 \<inter> roots l1) + card (roots c1 \<inter> roots l2) + card (roots c2 \<inter> roots l1) + card (roots c2 \<inter> roots l2)) \<le> 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given five different real functions c1, c2, l1, l2 and roots, find the maximum possible number of distinct real roots that can be shared among any two of these functions. The maximum number of shared roots is 11.
